title: Florence — The Duel of Giants
teaser: Michelangelo and Leonardo compete for the same wall. The Renaissance peaks.

art.label: Art
art.content:
Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo Buonarroti are both commissioned to paint opposing walls of the Sala del Cinquecento in Florence's Palazzo Vecchio. Leonardo works on The Battle of Anghiari; Michelangelo on The Battle of Cascina. Neither finishes — but the rivalry electrifies all of Florence.

Meanwhile, Michelangelo's David is unveiled in Piazza della Signoria. Raphael, just 21, arrives in Florence and begins absorbing both masters' techniques.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Niccolò Machiavelli is serving as Florence's Second Chancellor, running diplomatic missions across Italy. He's watching Cesare Borgia's ruthless statecraft firsthand — notes that will fuel The Prince (written 1513). Ludovico Ariosto is drafting early cantos of Orlando Furioso in Ferrara, fusing medieval romance with Renaissance irony.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Erasmus of Rotterdam publishes Enchiridion militis Christiani (Handbook of a Christian Knight), arguing for an inner, philosophical Christianity over empty ritual. Neoplatonism still dominates Florentine intellectual life — Marsilio Ficino's translations of Plato shaped this entire generation. The idea that beauty reveals divine truth is taken literally: art IS philosophy made visible.

hist.label: History
hist.content: Italy is a chessboard of warring city-states and foreign powers. France and Spain are fighting over Naples. Pope Julius II is scheming to expand papal territory. Florence, recently rid of Savonarola's theocratic rule (burned 1498), is a fragile republic under Piero Soderini. Columbus made his fourth and final voyage. Portugal's empire expands in the Indian Ocean.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: The collision is staggering: Machiavelli watches power while Leonardo and Michelangelo depict it on the same walls. Machiavelli personally knew both artists — he helped arrange Leonardo's commission. Erasmus's rational Christianity and Florence's Neoplatonism are two faces of the same coin: both reject medieval scholasticism for something more human, more direct. The David isn't just sculpture — it's a political statement: the small republic standing against giants.
conn.funFact: When the committee chose where to place the David, both Leonardo and Botticelli were on the panel. Leonardo suggested hiding it in a loggia. He was outvoted.

title: Paris — The Year Everything Changed
teaser: The Eiffel Tower rises. Van Gogh paints Starry Night. Nietzsche collapses. Bergson rethinks time itself.

art.label: Art
art.content: Vincent van Gogh paints The Starry Night from the asylum at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence — swirling cosmos as felt truth, not observed fact. Paul Gauguin has fled to Brittany, painting The Yellow Christ, pushing toward symbolism. Claude Monet is deep into his series paintings. Paul Cézanne quietly revolutionizes form in Aix-en-Provence — the bridge between Impressionism and everything that follows.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: Guy de Maupassant publishes Fort comme la mort, his penultimate novel before syphilis claims his mind. W.B. Yeats releases The Wanderings of Oisin, his first major work. Mark Twain publishes A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court — time travel as social satire. Tolstoy has just finished The Kreutzer Sonata, banned for its frank treatment of sexuality.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Friedrich Nietzsche collapses in Turin in January, embracing a beaten horse — his productive life ends. Twilight of the Idols is published this year, declaring "God is dead" to a world not yet ready to listen. Henri Bergson publishes Essai sur les données immédiates de la conscience (Time and Free Will), arguing that lived time is fundamentally different from clock time — a direct challenge to scientific determinism.

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Eiffel Tower opens for the World's Fair, built in just 2 years — the tallest structure on Earth. It's meant to be temporary. The fair celebrates the centennial of the French Revolution. Brazil becomes a republic. The Meiji Constitution takes effect in Japan. In London, the dock workers' strike marks a turning point for organized labor. The Scramble for Africa is in full swing.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Bergson's insight that time as lived ≠ time as measured connects directly to what the painters are doing: Van Gogh doesn't paint what the sky looks like — he paints what it feels like. Nietzsche's death-of-God moment and Van Gogh's asylum visions share the same vertigo: a world where old certainties dissolve into swirling energy. The Eiffel Tower — pure engineering, no ornament — embodies the same tension: is modernity beautiful or monstrous? Maupassant famously ate lunch in the Tower's restaurant because "it's the only place in Paris where you can't see the damn thing."
conn.funFact: Van Gogh's brother Theo tried to sell his paintings at the 1889 World's Fair. Almost no one bought. A century later, those paintings would sell for $80+ million each.

title: The Modernist Explosion
teaser: Joyce, Eliot, Woolf, Wittgenstein — in a single year, the old world of art and thought is detonated.

art.label: Art
art.content: Bauhaus is in full swing in Weimar under Gropius — Klee, Kandinsky, and Moholy-Nagy teaching there. Man Ray creates his first "rayographs" in Paris. Mondrian pushes into pure geometric abstraction. In Mexico, Diego Rivera begins his first major mural at the Escuela Nacional Preparatoria. The Salon des Indépendants shows 5,000+ works — the art world is exploding in every direction simultaneously.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content: The single greatest year in literary history? James Joyce's Ulysses is published in Paris by Sylvia Beach (banned in the US and UK). T.S. Eliot publishes The Waste Land — modernism's anthem. Virginia Woolf's Jacob's Room appears. Marcel Proust dies in November, leaving In Search of Lost Time unfinished. Rainer Maria Rilke completes the Duino Elegies and Sonnets to Orpheus in a single feverish burst. Hermann Hesse publishes Siddhartha.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content: Ludwig Wittgenstein's Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus is published in English (German edition 1921). Its final line — "Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent" — becomes philosophy's most quoted sentence. Martin Heidegger is lecturing at Freiburg, developing the ideas that will become Being and Time (1927). The Vienna Circle is forming around Moritz Schlick — logical positivism is about to reshape everything.

hist.label: History
hist.content: The Soviet Union is formally established in December. Mussolini marches on Rome in October — fascism takes power in Italy. The Ottoman Empire collapses; Turkey becomes a republic under Atatürk. The BBC begins broadcasting. Egypt gains nominal independence from Britain. Tutankhamun's tomb is discovered by Howard Carter. The world is 4 years past WWI and still reeling.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content: Everything connects through fragmentation. Eliot's Waste Land is fragments shored against ruins — literally. Joyce's Ulysses fragments narrative into a dozen styles. The Bauhaus fragments art into geometry. Wittgenstein fragments language into logical atoms. Why? Because the war fragmented everything — empires, bodies, certainties. Modernism isn't a style; it's the art of a shattered world trying to reassemble itself. Proust dies trying to capture all of time; Wittgenstein insists we stay silent about what we can't capture. Two responses to the same impossibility.
conn.funFact: Eliot dedicated The Waste Land to Ezra Pound, who edited it ruthlessly — cutting it nearly in half. The original draft, discovered in 1968, shows Pound may have been the greatest editor in literary history.

title: Baghdad — The Translation of Everything
teaser: While Europe sleeps in its Dark Age, Baghdad builds the world's largest mosque and translates all of Greek thought into Arabic. Philosophy, science, and literature converge in the richest city on Earth.

art.label: Art
art.content:
Caliph al-Mutawakkil commissions the Great Mosque of Samarra (completed ~851) — the largest mosque in the world, with its extraordinary spiral minaret, the Malwiya, rising 52 meters in a coiling ramp to the sky. It's architecture as cosmic statement: the spiral as infinite ascent toward God.

Islamic art is inventing an entirely new visual language. Banned from depicting the human form in sacred contexts, artists develop the arabesque — infinitely repeating geometric and vegetal patterns that encode mathematical relationships into pure beauty. Lustre-glazed ceramics from Samarra shimmer with metallic iridescence, a technique no other civilization has mastered. The art isn't decorative — it's theological: infinite pattern as proof of divine unity.

lit.label: Literature
lit.content:
Al-Jahiz (776–868/9) is at the height of his powers in Basra and Baghdad — the most original prose writer in the Arabic language. His Kitab al-Hayawan (Book of Animals) is a seven-volume encyclopedia that fuses zoology, philosophy, humor, and anecdote into something utterly unprecedented. He describes food chains, environmental adaptation, and animal mimicry — observations that prefigure evolutionary thinking by a millennium.

The earliest core of the One Thousand and One Nights is circulating as oral tradition, absorbing Persian, Indian, and Arabic tales into its frame narrative. Abu Tammam compiles the Hamasa, the great anthology of pre-Islamic and early Arabic poetry — curating the literary past just as translators are importing the Greek one.

phil.label: Philosophy
phil.content:
Al-Kindi (c. 801–873), the "Philosopher of the Arabs," is active in Baghdad — the first systematic attempt to reconcile Greek philosophy with Islamic revelation. He argues that truth is truth regardless of its source, and that reason and faith illuminate each other. His On First Philosophy adapts Aristotelian metaphysics for monotheism.

The Mu'tazila school of rational theology dominates intellectual life (until al-Mutawakkil suppresses it around 848–851). They insist the Quran was created, not eternal — a position with enormous philosophical implications: it means sacred texts are subject to reason. The suppression of the Mu'tazila marks one of intellectual history's great what-ifs.

hist.label: History
hist.content:
Baghdad is the largest city in the world — population near one million. The Abbasid Caliphate stretches from North Africa to Central Asia. The House of Wisdom (Bayt al-Hikma) functions as library and translation center, where scholars render Greek, Persian, Syriac, and Sanskrit texts into Arabic.

Hunayn ibn Ishaq (808–873), a Nestorian Christian, leads the translation movement — personally translating 129 works of Galen and key texts of Plato and Aristotle. The translation isn't passive reception: scholars improve, annotate, and extend what they translate. Meanwhile, al-Mutawakkil moves the capital to Samarra (836–892), building a new imperial city from scratch — the Versailles of the medieval world, stretching 40 km along the Tigris.

conn.label: Connections
conn.content:
The deep connection: translation as creation. Hunayn ibn Ishaq translating Galen isn't just preservation — it's transformation. Greek ideas pass through Syriac into Arabic and emerge changed, adapted, sharpened. Al-Kindi philosophizes in a language Aristotle never spoke, and asks questions Aristotle never imagined. Al-Jahiz writes zoology that reads like literature, because in Arabic intellectual culture, eloquence and knowledge are inseparable — the word adab means both "literature" and "refinement of mind."

And here's the historical irony: everything these scholars translate and extend will travel back to Europe via Islamic Spain and Sicily, seeding the very Renaissance that posterity will celebrate as "Western" achievement. Without 850 Baghdad, there is no 1504 Florence.
conn.funFact: Al-Jahiz allegedly died when a tower of books in his private library collapsed on him. The greatest Arabic prose stylist, killed by his own collection — literature's most on-brand death.
